evidence_span: The stress dependency of steady-state creep can be expressed by the so-called strain rate sensitivity $n = d l n$ (creep rate)/dln(stress). n was expected to be a constant, at least over significant ranges of stress, but instead was found to increase continuously with stress level [9].

source_id: STP1295-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_11th Volume_005_chunk5
evidence_span: Figure 7 is an updated diagram, first presented in 1986 [20], showing in-pile and out-of-pile corrosion rates versus the mean size of these intermetallics. The corrosion rates are higher (except for the 500°C steam autoclave tests) when the size of the intermetallics is very small (especially smaller as usual). However, in BWRs this effect can only be seen at burnups in excess of about 20 MWd/kgU [24]. Coarse intermetallics, on the other hand, lead to nodular corrosion in BWRs as well as in 500°C steam (closed dots in the figure), but are harmless in PWRs.

source_id: STP1295-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_11th Volume_005_chunk5
evidence_span: The effectiveness of a single step at (constant) temperature T_i (K) during a timespan t_i (h) is given through k·t_i·exp( - T_A / T_i ) with T_A = 3254 K The "rate factor" k is arbitrarily chosen as k = 1E14 (h⁻¹) An accumulated particle growth parameter PGP after i annealing steps is then defined by PGP = Σ_i k·t_i·exp( - T_A / T_i )

source_id: STP1295-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_11th Volume_005_chunk5
evidence_span: The effectiveness of the initial quenching process from β- to α-phase can be approximately considered by adding the quotient 0.45/CDR to this sum, where CDR means the cooling down rate in the α phase in K/s

source_id: STP1295-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_11th Volume_005_chunk5
evidence_span: For in-reactor corrosion, it has been shown that the size distribution of the intermetallics can be influenced by the fast neutron flux through the acceleration of dissolution processes as well as through the acceleration of foreign atom diffusion within the Zr lattice. At BWR operating temperature, the dissolution of initially fine intermetallics may be the reason for the increase of the corrosion rate at burnups in excess of about 20 MWd/kgU.

source_id: STP1295-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_11th Volume_005_chunk9
evidence_span: corrosion tested under static conditions in steam at 673 K and 10.3 MPa for a total of 220 days

source_id: STP1295-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_11th Volume_005_chunk9
evidence_span: The order of corrosion resistance in 673-K steam was Zr2 > 1Nb–Zr4 > Zr4

evidence_span: The order of corrosion resistance in 673-K steam was Zr2 > 1Nb–Zr4 > Zr4

source_id: STP1295-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_11th Volume_005_chunk9
evidence_span: Several transitions were observed in the corrosion kinetic curve of 1Nb–Zr4 and Zr2

source_id: STP1295-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_11th Volume_005_chunk9
evidence_span: Several transitions were observed in the corrosion kinetic curve of 1Nb–Zr4 and Zr2

source_id: STP1295-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_11th Volume_005_chunk9
evidence_span: only the first transition was observed in the curve of Zr4

source_id: STP1295-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_11th Volume_005_chunk9
evidence_span: Oxide structure in the pre-transition region on Zr4 was analyzed to be in the following order from the outside surface: columnar m-ZrO2, t-ZrO2 layer, substoichiometric Zr oxide layer, and α-Zr matrix

source_id: STP1295-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_11th Volume_005_chunk9
evidence_span: The t-ZrO2 layer was approximately 50 to 80 nm thick

source_id: STP1295-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_11th Volume_005_chunk9
evidence_span: the substoichiometric Zr oxide layer was approximately 100 to 200 nm

source_id: STP1295-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_11th Volume_005_chunk9
evidence_span: These layers were absent in the microstructure of the oxide in the post-transition region

source_id: STP1295-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_11th Volume_005_chunk9
evidence_span: the substoichiometric Zr oxide layer consisted of m-ZrO2 grains that were less than 10 nm in diameter

source_id: STP1295-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_11th Volume_005_chunk9
evidence_span: the t-ZrO2 layered structure and the substoichiometric Zr oxide layer structure were observed in the post-transition oxides on Zr2 and 1Nb–Zr4

source_id: STP1295-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_11th Volume_005_chunk9
evidence_span: the t-ZrO2 layered structure and the substoichiometric Zr oxide layer structure were observed in the post-transition oxides on Zr2 and 1Nb–Zr4

source_id: STP1295-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_11th Volume_005_chunk9
evidence_span: transformation of columnar grains to fine equiaxed grains had occurred near the lateral cracks and the incorporated intermetallic precipitates in post-transition oxides
